Example 23—Find the slope of the curve representing the equation 
\[ 
 y = \frac{2}{5} x^{2} - 2x 
\] when \( x = 1 \). 
The slope of the curve— 
\[
\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{2}{5} x^{2} - 2x \right) = \frac{2}{5} \cdot 2x - 2 = \frac{4}{5} x - 2
\] Hence when \( x = 1 \): 
\[
\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{4}{5}(1) - 2 = \frac{4}{5} - 2 = \frac{4}{5} - \frac{10}{5} = -\frac{6}{5}
\] Therefore at \( x = 1 \), the slope is \( -\frac{6}{5} \).

Example 24—Differentiate, with regard to \( t \), the function 
\[ 
 y = 9t^{5} - 9t^{4} + 5
\] 
\[

Simple Harmonic Motion— 
Simple harmonic motion can be represented as a more strict examination of simple harmonic motion. Suppose a crank of length \( 2 \) feet (Figure 15), starting from the position \( OX \), rotates at a constant angular heading direction. Let it have reached the position \( OA \) after \( t \) seconds has elapsed from the start; then the angle passed through in this interval of time \( AOM \) is \( \theta \) seconds, since the angular distance covered in \( 1 \) sec. = radians and the angular distance in \( t \) seconds of radians.
